---
title: "Hands-on Exercise - Session 1: Geospatial Data Wrangling with R"
execute: 
  warning: false
date: "2023-03-19"
---


# 1.1 Getting Started

## 1.1.1 Installing and Loading R Packages

In this section, I will install and load the required R packages, being tidyverse and sf libraries/packages. Here we use the pacman library to install and load the libraries in case it is needed.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
pacman::p_load(tidyverse, sf)
```
:::


# 1.2 Importing Data into R-Studio

In this section, we will import the data previously extracted from the web into our R session. Note that the data should be stored in the same folder as the R repository.

## 1.2.1 Import data in shp file format

Here we use the function st_read to read the files stored under the shp format.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", 
                layer = "MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' from data source 
  `C:\p-haas\IS415\Hands-on_Ex\Hands-on_Ex01\data\geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 323 features and 15 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
cpg <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", 
                layer = "CyclingPathGazette")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Reading layer `CyclingPathGazette' from data source 
  `C:\p-haas\IS415\Hands-on_Ex\Hands-on_Ex01\data\geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 2248 features and 0 fields
Geometry type: MULTILINESTRING
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 11854.32 ymin: 28347.98 xmax: 42626.09 ymax: 48948.15
CRS:           NA
```
:::
:::


## 1.2.2 Import data in kml format

Here we use the function st_read to read the files stored under the kml format. Note that in this second case, we do not include the layer in the code.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
psl <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial/preschools-location.kml")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Reading layer `PRESCHOOLS_LOCATION' from data source 
  `C:\p-haas\IS415\Hands-on_Ex\Hands-on_Ex01\data\geospatial\preschools-location.kml' 
  using driver `KML'
Simple feature collection with 1925 features and 2 fields
Geometry type: POINT
Dimension:     XYZ
Bounding box:  xmin: 103.6824 ymin: 1.247759 xmax: 103.9897 ymax: 1.462134
z_range:       zmin: 0 zmax: 0
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
```
:::
:::


# 1.3 Checking Content of Data Frame Simple Feature

## 1.3.1 Working with st_geometry()

Note that st_geometry() can be replaced by mpsz\$geometry or mpsz\[\[1\]\]


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
st_geometry(mpsz)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Geometry set for 323 features 
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21
First 5 geometries:
```
:::
:::


Notice that the print only displays basic information of the feature class such as type of geometry, the geographic extent of the features and the coordinate system of the data.

## 1.3.2 Working with glimpse()

The function glimpse() reports information about the data type of every column or field.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
glimpse(mpsz)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

Columns: 16

head(mpsz, n=5)
```

# 1.4 Plotting Geospatial Data

## 1.4.1 Plotting - Polygon Feature


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(mpsz)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


The default plot of an sf object is a multi-plot of all attributes, up to a reasonable maximum as shown above. We can, however, choose to plot only the geometry by using the code chunk below.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(st_geometry(mpsz))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


Alternatively, we can also choose the plot the sf object by using a specific attribute as shown in the code chunk below.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(mpsz["PLN_AREA_N"])
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## 1.4.2 Plotting - Polyline Feature


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(cpg)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(st_geometry(cpg))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## 1.4.3 Plotting - Multipoint Feature


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(psl)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(st_geometry(psl))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672}
:::
